","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2024-04-05T23:43:57.347Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":119,"readers_count":118,"score":28.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":461418,"topic_slug":"thriftybot-absolute-magnetic-encoder-resolution","display_username":"viggy96","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":45905,"username":"Freya_Basteln","name":"","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/f/f1d935/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24613,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"418 Mentor | Tries to be smart"},"post_url":"/t/thriftybot-absolute-magnetic-encoder-resolution/461418/3","custom_user_title":"418 Mentor | Tries to be smart","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3353143,"name":"Eric Ward","username":"bathtubed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bathtubed/{size}/220364_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-05T23:46:07.583Z","cooked":"

The ThriftyBot encoders output an analog voltage based on the sensor reading.

To connect it to a spark max you need to use the analog input on the sensor interface, which is usually done with an analog breakout board. SPARK MAX Data Port Breakout Board - REV Robotics (universal breakout board)

The resolution you get will thus depend on the resolution of the ADC in the spark max, which is 12-bits, or 4096 ticks corresponding to the full rotation of the thrifty encoder.

The product page for the TTB encoder seems like it’s PWM not analog?

EDIT: nvm you’re right

The Thrifty Bot

Thrifty Absolute Magnetic Encoder

  ﻿Note: Molded plastic cases have begun shipping with all encoder orders!﻿ The Thrifty Absolute Magnetic Encoder was designed to provide teams a lower cost option for absolute position sensing. Simply plug the included 3-wire PWM style cable...

Price: USD 29.99

This is the one my team uses for absolute positioning of arms, I’ve quite liked it this year. Maybe there’s a PWM version I’m unaware of.

I checked the redux page: (HELIUM Canandcoder) it claims 14 bit precision, but I think that sort of depends on the Spark Max PWM sampling rate?

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2024-04-05T23:58:47.043Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":96,"readers_count":95,"score":24.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":461418,"topic_slug":"thriftybot-absolute-magnetic-encoder-resolution","display_username":"viggy96","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":35208,"username":"bathtubed","name":"Eric Ward","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bathtubed/{size}/220364_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24613,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"418 Mentor | Tries to be smart"},"post_url":"/t/thriftybot-absolute-magnetic-encoder-resolution/461418/7","custom_user_title":"418 Mentor | Tries to be smart","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3353156,"name":"Emerson OHara","username":"Emerson1706","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/emerson1706/{size}/174702_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-06T00:00:03.053Z","cooked":"

The sparkmax analog input isn’t perfect, id recommend using a PWM encoder if wiring directly to the sparkmax. The Canandencoder works well and comes with a cable that plugs directly into the sparkmax.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2024-04-06T00:00:03.053Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":91,"readers_count":90,"score":48.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":461418,"topic_slug":"thriftybot-absolute-magnetic-encoder-resolution","display_username":"Emerson OHara","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":43759,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1706 Drive Coach | 9401 Mentor | #TeamThrifty"},"post_url":"/t/thriftybot-absolute-magnetic-encoder-resolution/461418/8","custom_user_title":"1706 Drive Coach | 9401 Mentor | #TeamThrifty","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3353165,"name":"Eric Ward","username":"bathtubed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bathtubed/{size}/220364_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-06T00:11:41.337Z","cooked":"

No we’re using Talon SRX for ours, which actually only has a 10 bit ADC.

Usually that’s good enough for us. On our shooter arm, we use a 1:4 gear to scale the quarter rotation of our aiming arm to the 360 rotation of the sensor to get the full value.

I’d imagine @Emerson1706 is probably right to doubt the 12 bit ADC of the sparkmax. Those last 2 bits may be a good deal noisier. I personally haven’t worked with analog sensors and spark-maxes, nor with PWM analog sensors.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2024-04-06T00:11:41.337Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":89,"readers_count":88,"score":22.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":461418,"topic_slug":"thriftybot-absolute-magnetic-encoder-resolution","display_username":"Eric Ward","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":24613,"username":"viggy96","name":"viggy96","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/viggy96/{size}/252784_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":35208,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3637 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/thriftybot-absolute-magnetic-encoder-resolution/461418/9","custom_user_title":"3637 Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3353178,"name":"guineawheek","username":"guineawheek","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/guineawheek/{size}/180797_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-06T00:39:57.607Z","cooked":"
viggy96:

Still can’t find specs on the product page for the Redux CANandcoder, regarding sensor resolution.

The Canandcoder’s sensor resolution is 14 bits, and the PWM output also runs at that resolution . You’ll get some nonlinearity based on the magnet mounting for any magnetic encoder on the FRC market, in the neighborhood of 1 degree, so utility of resolution beyond 10-12 bits is debatable.

bathtubed:

I checked the redux page: (HELIUM Canandcoder ) it claims 14 bit precision, but I think that sort of depends on the Spark Max PWM sampling rate?

The Spark Max’s duty cycle input is sensitive down to at least 14 bits of resolution, so it can sense single-bit changes in value from our encoder.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2024-04-06T00:39:57.607Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":6,"quote_count":2,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":83,"readers_count":82,"score":96.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":461418,"topic_slug":"thriftybot-absolute-magnetic-encoder-resolution","display_username":"guineawheek","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":31855,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"software @ redux robotics"},"post_url":"/t/thriftybot-absolute-magnetic-encoder-resolution/461418/10","custom_user_title":"software @ redux robotics","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3353182,"name":"Eric Ward","username":"bathtubed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bathtubed/{size}/220364_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-06T00:45:05.414Z","cooked":"
guineawheek:

You’ll get some nonlinearity based on the magnet mounting for any magnetic encoder on the FRC market, in the neighborhood of 1 degree

I’d be interested in learning more about this, can you go more in depth or link to something that does?

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2024-04-06T00:45:05.414Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":73,"readers_count":72,"score":29.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":461418,"topic_slug":"thriftybot-absolute-magnetic-encoder-resolution","display_username":"Eric Ward","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":35208,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3637 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/thriftybot-absolute-magnetic-encoder-resolution/461418/11","custom_user_title":"3637 Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3353187,"name":"Eeshwar Krishnan","username":"Eeshwar","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/eeshwar/{size}/195169_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-06T01:06:29.773Z","cooked":"

So there are 3 main factors that affect the linearity of a magnetic encoder in general: The natural linearity of the encoder, the mounting of the magnet it senses, and the quality of the magnet it senses.

The natural linearity of the encoder is usually a spec in its datasheet, this is just nonlinearity due to a few factors (for an analog encoder this is usually a combination of the linearity of the magnetic sense element as well as the linearity of the digital to analog converter that produces the voltage output).

The mounting of the magnet it senses affects linearity because it changes the read values by the encoder as the magnet rotates. The high level oversimplified idea here is that a magnetic encoder has 2 hall effect sensors at 90 degree angles, and it uses the measurements from these two (specifically the arctangent of the values) in order to calculate the angle the magnet is at. If the magnet isn’t perfectly centered on the chip, or is slightly tilted, then it will introduce a sinusoidal nonlinearity artifact in the resulting data.

One tool you can use to get a rough understanding of how this impacts the resulting performance is the MPS Magnetic Simulation Tool. Although it technically won’t work with magnetic encoders not made by MPS, it will give you a rough idea of how performance changes as you mount a magnet off center. Some manufacturers will specifically rate their encoders for INL (integral nonlinearity) vs displacement, and some will just have a maximum displacement for guaranteed precision.

The reason why you will almost always get nonlinearity from mounting a magnetic encoder in FRC is these numbers are generally on the range of 0.1-0.3mm for maximum performance. Angular tolerances are even more important, as little as 0.05 degrees of tilt/wobble can start showing up on the lowest bits. 1 degree INL is our estimation for an “average case” scenario.

","post_number":12,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2024-04-06T01:06:46.352Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":11,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":74,"readers_count":73,"score":79.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":461418,"topic_slug":"thriftybot-absolute-magnetic-encoder-resolution","display_username":"Eeshwar Krishnan","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://tinyurl.com/27ggbdbu","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"MPS - Magnetic Simulation Tool","clicks":5}],"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":35208,"username":"bathtubed","name":"Eric Ward","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bathtubed/{size}/220364_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53758,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Redux Robotics"},"post_url":"/t/thriftybot-absolute-magnetic-encoder-resolution/461418/12","custom_user_title":"Redux Robotics","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3353191,"name":"Eric Ward","username":"bathtubed","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bathtubed/{size}/220364_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-06T01:25:13.551Z","cooked":"

Oh, awesome, thanks so much for the detailed response.

My mental model was always of a potentiometer which is linear.
The offcenter atan2 artifacts make a lot of sense.

So you’re saying the sensors themselves are non-linear, I guess its probably something like inverse square or cube for distance from magnet pole?

","post_number":13,"post_type":1,"posts_count":15,"updated_at":"2024-04-06T01:25:13.551Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":12,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":68,"readers_count":67,"score":48.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":461418,"topic_slug":"thriftybot-absolute-magnetic-encoder-resolution","display_username":"Eric Ward","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":53758,"username":"Eeshwar","name":"Eeshwar Krishnan","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/eeshwar/{size}/195169_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":35208,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3637 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/thriftybot-absolute-magnetic-encoder-resolution/461418/13","custom_user_title":"3637 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3353193,"name":"Eeshwar Krishnan","username":"Eeshwar","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/eeshwar/{size}/195169_2.png","created_at":"2024-04-06T01:31:55.466Z","cooked":"

Its actually relatively linear displacement vs INL for short distances. Its a weird trigonometric relationship due to the arctangent. However, over longer distances, it is inverse cube since the magnetic field strength follows an inverse cube.

There is basically a range where the strength falloff doesn’t really matter, so it follows the trigonometric formula, then after that the strength falloff is enough to affect the sensor, so it becomes inverse cube. That exact distance heavily depends on the sensor and the magnet but in my experience its around 1-3mm from the edge of the magnet.
